Definition: To reduce in degree or intensity. Often used for things like storms, fears, or emotions.
To regard with extreme dislike or hatred. A stronger form of 'dislike'.
Highly skilled or proficient at something. Often used to describe a person's abilities.
To make more beautiful or attractive. Commonly used for decorating objects or people.
Concerned with beauty or the appreciation of beauty. Related to visual appeal.
Able to move quickly and easily. Can also refer to mental sharpness.
To ease a pain or burden. Often used in medical or emotional contexts.
To make something that is bad or unsatisfactory better. A formal improvement.
Friendly and pleasant in manner. Often used to describe personalities.
More than enough in size or capacity. Implies generosity or sufficiency.
To entertain or cause laughter. Can also mean to distract pleasantly.
To look forward to or expect. Also means to prepare in advance.
To assess the value or quality of something. Often used for property or skills.
Very enthusiastic or passionate. Describes strong emotions or dedication.
Based on random choice or personal whim. Lacks reason or system.
Having sharp judgment. Often implies cleverness and insight.
To achieve or reach a goal. Usually through effort or skill.
To prevent something bad from happening. Can also mean to turn away.
To signal or summon someone by gesture. Can imply an invitation or temptation.
To make someone or something seem less important. Often used to criticize.
To confuse or puzzle completely. Often leaves someone unsure of what to do.
Not sharp or pointed. Also means being very direct in speech.
To support or strengthen something. Can be emotional, physical, or abstract.
Quick and energetic. Often used to describe walking or weather.
Able to float. Also used to describe a cheerful or optimistic mood.
Given to sudden changes in mood or behavior. Unpredictable or impulsive.
To criticize or punish severely. Often for wrongdoing.
A factual written account of events. Usually in chronological order.
Mercy or leniency shown toward an offender. Often by someone in authority.
To force someone to do something. Often through pressure or threats.
Logical and consistent. Ideas or speech that make sense together.
To begin or start. A formal synonym for 'start'.
Sympathy and concern for others' suffering. Leads to a desire to help.
To force or drive someone to act. Can be through pressure or necessity.
Complete and including everything necessary. Covers all relevant parts.
To agree or share the same opinion. Often used in formal contexts.
To accept or allow behavior that is morally wrong. Often by ignoring it.
To grant or bestow something. Also means to discuss or consult.
To follow rules or standards. To fit in with expectations.
To confuse or surprise someone. Can also mean to prove wrong.
To call upon or bring into existence, often magically. Also used for ideas.
General agreement among a group. Often reached after discussion.
Easily seen or noticed. Attracts attention due to being obvious.
To communicate or transport. Express an idea clearly.
Abundant in supply or quantity. Large in number or amount.
To confirm or support with evidence. Often used in research or law.
Skillful in deception or cleverness. Can be negative or positive.
Showing fearlessness and determination. Brave in the face of danger.
To interpret or make sense of something unclear. Often a code or message.
To postpone or delay. Can also mean to yield to someoneâ€™s opinion.
Open resistance or bold disobedience. Often used in the context of challenging authority.
Done consciously and intentionally. Can also mean to think carefully before deciding.
A person's outward behavior or appearance. Reflects attitude and personality.
To publicly declare something wrong or evil. Often used in political or social criticism.
To show or represent something in words or images. Often used in art or storytelling.
To obtain something from a source. Can refer to information, meaning, or origin.
To become worse in condition or quality. Used for health, relationships, or materials.
Showing steady and careful effort. Describes hardworking and responsible behavior.
To make or become smaller or less. Can refer to value, size, or importance.
Careful and cautious in speech or actions. Avoids drawing attention or causing offense.
A feeling of contempt or scorn. Often directed at something considered unworthy.
A strong feeling of fear or worry. Often due to unexpected trouble.
To speak of in a disrespectful way. Belittling someone or something.
To scatter or spread out. Used for people, objects, or substances.
Disagreement with a commonly held opinion. Often used in politics or debate.
To twist out of shape or meaning. Can be physical or related to truth.
To go in different directions. Used for paths, opinions, or data.
Easily managed or trained. Often describes calm and obedient people or animals.
Inactive or asleep, but capable of becoming active. Often used for volcanoes or skills.
Doubtful or suspicious. Something that may not be completely true or reliable.
Unconventional or slightly strange. Often describes behavior or appearance.
Fluent and persuasive in speaking or writing. Shows strong expression of ideas.
To escape or avoid, often cleverly. Can refer to capture or understanding.
To make something more attractive by adding details. Can also mean exaggeration.
To represent or express something clearly. Often used for ideas in a person or object.
The ability to understand and share another's feelings. Stronger than sympathy.
A serious effort or attempt to achieve something. Often used in formal contexts.
To publicly support or approve something. Often used in advertising or politics.
To improve or increase in value or quality. Used for appearance, performance, etc.
Mysterious and difficult to understand. Often refers to people or expressions.
To improve or make richer. Can refer to knowledge, value, or quality.
To involve something as a necessary part. Often used in responsibilities or consequences.
To count or list one by one. Often used in academic or legal writing.
To imagine or picture something in the future. Often used for goals or plans.
Fair and impartial. Used in legal, business, or social contexts.
Unpredictable or inconsistent. Often used for behavior or movement.
To gradually wear away. Often used for natural processes like wind or water.
To avoid or deliberately stay away from. Often for ethical or personal reasons.
To set up or create something permanently. Used for rules, systems, or organizations.
Respect or admiration, often for a person. Also means to value something highly.
To escape or avoid, often illegally or cleverly. Used for taxes, questions, etc.
To assess or judge the value or quality. Common in academic and work contexts.
To bring a feeling, memory, or image to mind. Often used in art or writing.
To overstate or enlarge beyond truth. Often used to emphasize or impress.
To be very good at something. To perform better than others.
To serve as a good example. Also used to clarify a point.
Thorough and complete. Covers all aspects or details.
Very exciting or thrilling. Causes happiness or stimulation.
To clear from blame or guilt. Often used in legal contexts.
To speed up the process or progress. Often used in logistics or business.
